segments.source_content: Vercelâ€™s VP of Product, Lee Rob, explained on X that Vercel is â€œreverting all edge rendering back to Node.js.â€ If youâ€™re using Vercel (and probably even if you donâ€™t), youâ€™ll know that Vercel has pushed â€œedgeâ€ as a concept for a long time. On the one hand, edge means that compute is run near to where a user accessing a site hosted on Vercel is located. On the other hand, it also means that this compute is run on an â€œedge runtime,â€ which is built on V8 and not on Node.js. While the concept of running compute near to the end users sound appealing, the advantages quickly disappear if data needs to be loaded from a central location (which very often is the case). At the same time, development teams are often struggling to adapt workload to the limited subset of APIs available on the edge runtime. Now it seams Vercel has come to the conclusion that overall, the challenges for developers outweigh the limited benefits, and is therefore reverting to centralized Node.js runtimes. I appreciate their transparency around this! If you want more details, Theo made a [video](https://youtu.be/lAGE-k1Zfrg?si=5SP4hyoFkixTsh-y) about it.

segments.source_content:
- **Build AI Chat Interfaces In Minutes** - High quality conversational AI interfaces with a few lines of code.
- **React Components & Hooks** - `<AiChat />` for UI and `useChatAdapter` hook for easy integration.
- **Flexible Adapters** - For `ChatGPT`, `LangChain` and `HuggingFace`, and an API to **Create Your Own Adapter** for any backend.
- **Synchronise UI state with AI backends** in an optimal way.
- **Markdown Streaming** - Render LLM markdown as it's being generated.
- **Zero Dependencies** - Lightweight codebase.

segments.source_content: This week saw the release of React Native 0.74, a major milestone for the community! The latest version makes â€œbridgeless modeâ€ the default for new projects using the New Architecture (with the next release, 0.75, the New Arch will become the default, too). Both can still be turned off if needed, but they clearly represent the future of React Native, and over the last months especially, A LOT of libraries have added support for both. But thereâ€™s more: RN 0.74 includes Yoga 3.0. There are very few breaking changes and deprecations, but itâ€™s still worth checking them out in the [release notes](https://reactnative.dev/blog/2024/04/22/release-0.74).
